title: Unilateral combination of small doughs
vignette: Two neighbours each have less than the threshold that obligates dough-offering. One quietly kneads both portions together, pushing the total above the limit. Must challah now be separated from both portions?

options.text: Yes; combining doughs creates a joint liability to give challah.
No; each owner is liable only for her own initial portion.

title: Dividing after kneading to avoid the tithe
vignette: A household kneads a large batch, then splits it into sub-loaves each below the threshold, hoping to escape the challah obligation. Is the stratagem valid?

options.text: Stratagem fails; obligation fixed at kneading.
Stratagem works; final loaf size determines liability.

title: Accepting dough from a non-Jewish baker
vignette: A Jew buys raw dough from a gentile who already kneaded it. Must the buyer separate challah now, or is the batch exempt?

options.text: Obligated once the Jew acquires; ownership triggers mitzvah.
Exempt; obligation rests on the kneader, not the purchaser.

title: Size of the priest’s share – home cook vs. commercial bakery
vignette: Torah leaves the challah amount undefined. Should a home cook give 1/24 of the dough while an industrial baker gives only 1/48, or should there be a single uniform rate?

options.text: Differentiate – larger share from households, smaller from bakeries.
Uniform minimal share for all; treat everyone equally.

title: Handling challah that became ritually impure
vignette: Separated challah turns tamei and may not be eaten by a priest. May the owner feed it to dogs, or must it be burned?

options.text: Burn it; sacred food must not be profaned.
Feed to animals; better utilitarian use than waste.

title: Exporting challah from the Diaspora to Israel
vignette: Diaspora Jews (where challah is rabbinic) wish to send their separated portion to priests in Israel. Is the extra logistic cost obligatory altruism or needless?

options.text: Send it; honouring the priestly gift overrides inconvenience.
Keep/discard locally; no duty to incur shipping expense.

title: Mixtures of species and obligation
vignette: Barley dough (liable) is mixed with rice dough (exempt), reducing the ratio below majority. Does the mixture now require challah?

options.text: Yes; any amount of liable grain triggers challah.
No; sub-majority of liable grain is annulled.
